posts.name: Roman McCauley
posts.cooked: In a recent regional, our robot made over ten high goals which is quite a bit, but compared to other bots with vision, we did significantly better by just eyeballing our shots. We have been working on vision for a while now but we are thinking that after doing so well with no vision, is vision actually worth it?

posts.name: vargoose84
posts.cooked:
The eyeballing that you’re doing makes your driver take away focus on what’s happening on the field. The goal of any automated system is to make sure that the driver can worry about something else that can’t be automated.

Also I think because of field of view you won’t be able to eyeball shots very well that are at an angle that makes it hard to see if your robot is square with the hub or not. Then again if your driver has enough practice anything really can be done by human but it might prevent you from attaining the next level of driving.

posts.name: Gavan Davis
posts.cooked: I don’t completely eyeball the shots. While on our side of the field, I just eyeball it and have had really good accuracy doing so. We have a webcam mounted for shots on the other side of the field, but no limelight or anything like that. We don’t miss very often unless we’re getting defended.

posts.name: John Christiansen
posts.cooked:
I think you’ll find most of the top teams have some vision system.

That being said, if your strategy is to continue to shoot up against the fender, then you probably don’t need a vision system and can invest your time in other areas.  There are, however, some downsides to having to shoot right up against the goal however, specifically it takes additional time to drive to that location and can be easier to defend.

posts.name: Maddy Fahey
posts.cooked: Our team can vouch for the viability of manual alignment. After we struggled to get our limelight working, we found out in our first qual this weekend that our driver is incredible at lining up quickly and accurately, scoring 10-12 cargo in several matches. The lighting conditions at our field varied based on time of day, and the venue had a large window that messed with vision, so even if we had gotten things working, we might have had issues later on. We were only able to score on our half of the field since we didn’t have a camera (preference), but because we shoot from the tarmac line we had a good range of locations.

posts.name: Wolly :)
posts.cooked: Eyeballing is not better than visioning. If it was, none of the top teams would have Limelight(s) or other computer vision systems on their robot.

posts.name: Ethan Braun
posts.cooked: As a driver, with the combination of a much bigger target and swerve drive, it makes it really easy to be consistent without vision. However it still is a worthy investment in my book if you are shooting from multiple spots

posts.name: NewtonCrosby
posts.cooked:
This question is really completely relative to your ability to do vision processing.

This year’s goal is not that hard to hit, depending on how far away you are, we’re talking about the center of the goal +/- 5 degrees.  So, it’s not very hard for a driver to line up and be pretty consistent.

If you have a really competent driver, AND and really competent vision system you’ll be much better than you are with just a really competent driver.

If you have an average (or below average) driver, and an above average targeting system with vision, you’re driver’s skill level will increase by a lot.

So, succinctly, “No”.  Eyeballing is not better than visioning, but if you’re really good at visioning and not very good at visioning, then in your particular case eyeballing may produce more consistent gameplay.

Our robot is a high goal shooter, our make percentage is probably north of 80-85% of made shots.  Including missed shots, bounce outs, shooting while being defended, etc.  Our driver primarily lines up both centering the goal and managing the distance with vision augmentation.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
FWIW, Back in 2016, we used a camera with a calibrated crosshairs on it. Since the shots were one-at-a-time, and every single one counted, and we weren’t as good at software back then, and we had an awesome driver who could use that camera/crosshairs like no one’s business… it worked great.

Under today’s assumptions, I’d probably choose a different strategy. But, the targets, technology, and skill of our team has all changed.

posts.name: Chris Herzog
posts.cooked:
I agree with every word here on the advantage of vision over eyeballing - but I gotta say “Right on!” to your drive team - as far as eyeballs go, those seem like pretty good ones for sure!

But I’ll bet vision will be better but still, that drive team is got something going on for sure.

posts.name: UnofficialForth
posts.cooked: Good eyeballing is better than bad vision

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC Team 4272  Mentor | World's FLL Emcee

posts.custom_user_title: FRC Team 4272  Mentor | World's FLL Emcee

posts.name: JJ Sessa
posts.cooked:
@AdamHeard probably has some good insight on this. 973 has had some pretty successful runs with just a flashlight (16, for ? Amount of the season?), and other years (19) had some of the best vision assisted scoring.

With cots vision solutions it seems no brainer to get some vision up and running,  2016 was still in the dark ages of vision solutions and probably the the largest factor in manual flashlight aiming.

posts.name: Will
posts.cooked: you’re from 1806 right? you guys were so good and the dual intakes with the shooter that rotates vertically 360° is so cool your team should have won gkc

posts.name: Declan
posts.cooked:
jjsessa:

With cots vision solutions it seems no brainer to get some vision up and running, 2016 was still in the dark ages of vision solutions and probably the the largest factor in manual flashlight aiming.

This is kind of the key. PhotonVision and Limelight exist now and are pretty easy to use. There are clearly situations where you might be fine without vision, but it’s a competitive advantage even if you don’t strictly need it. There are some costs, but are these really greater than the increased driver practice now that the implementation cost is low due to off-the-shelf solutions?

posts.name: Woolly
posts.cooked:
Vision is worth it, as while we made up to (I think) 6 cycles (some being 1 ball cycles) by just shooting at the fender, vision allows you to shoot from a distance which gives you more options when dealing with defenders, and can reduce cycle time by reducing driving time. However, there were many teams, especially at this event that had vision with problems differentiating between green-lit reflective tape and say, the color-changing stadium lighting. That is to say that developing vision is a great idea, but you should always design your robot to be able to get by without it. The limelight/photon dropping out shouldn’t mean you have to go play defense. Still, the inherent issues with retro-reflective tape are well explained by the paper linked here: Zebravision 7.0 (thanks Zebracorns), and we have a couple of Jetson Nanos laying around our shop, so one option would be to look at making a more robust vision solution using team 900’s findings. Another potentially easier solution would be to actually fund-raise enough that we could afford things like limelights, and then do some investigation into how to mitigate  the issues we saw other teams having.

Oh and also, it’s more than ok to be proud of what we built, but maybe tone down the chest-thumping a bit. We built a very cool robot that had more potential than what we showed on the field, but we have a lot of work to do when it comes to refining our design process (and team process in general) such that we can get a robot this cool built and working right at say week 4 of build rather than week 4 of the competition season for 2023.

posts.name: Roman McCauley
posts.cooked: Wise words spoken from a wise man.

posts.name: Nolan Locke
posts.cooked: For our first two tournaments, we have had one person drive and one person control the turret. We steadily got better throughout the tournament, but still only up to ~80% accuracy. We decided to work on developing vision for fine-tuning the alignment, and manually put it in a rough guess of the location. Setting up limelight for that isn’t too hard if you already have one. It really depends on how many shots you miss out of the ones you score with manual aiming.

posts.name: Roman McCauley
posts.cooked: Afraid we aren’t using a limelight due to budget cuts.
